1.content:
Her music battled the raging storm outside as the wind howled against the window, sending rain lashing against it. Sydney closed the curtains and turned it up a little louder with a smile. She knew it wouldn't bother her father, Frederick, as he lived in the other wing of the house. Sometimes she loved that her father was well off, though there were other things missing from her life. Her mother, for instance. She had never worked up the courage to ask her father about her. The last time she did he went into a fit of rage and disappeared from the house for days. Something had obviously hurt him very badly and she didn't want to be the one to make him feel like that again.

She picked up her book, the newest Martin novel, and sank back into her bed. The mounds of cushions softened her fall and in the dim light of her bed side lamp she was once again snug and warm and settling into her book.

***


The next thing she knew, a loud crash woke her from slumber. She jolted awake and dropped the book on the floor with a loud thump. For a moment she didn't know what had happened and then it dawned on her that she'd fallen asleep. She shook herself awake and jumped from her bed. The crash resounded in her mind. It was sharp and high pitched, like the sound of glass breaking.

Rushing from her room, she hurried along the dark corridor, ignoring the darkened foyer over the balcony and tore into her father's room without so much as a knock. There she saw turmoil.

The bed had been turned upside down, the bedside table lay on it's side with all of it's contents strewn across the floor. The dresser mirror was cracked in a spider web and the curtains had been torn down from the poles. Worst of all, the huge sash window had been smashed inwards, glass scattered on the plush carpet.

Without another thought she ran forward, and peered out of the window into the dark night. A lone car was racing down their driveway and off into the night with a screech of tyres.

For a moment, Sydney was unable to move. Finally, the rain that pelted her got through and she realised she was getting wet. As she pulled herself back in she heard another crunch of glass and that's when she realised, her feet were lacerated.

What happened? Where is my father? Who was in that car? What now?
1.title: One Stormy Night...

11.content:
Ignoring the pain in her feet, Sydney ran out into the rain, screaming for her father as the car drove further and further out of sight. It was not until she could no longer see the car when she stopped and fell to her knees, crying. Someone had broken into her home and had taken her father. Worse, there was nothing she could have done to stop it. "Why did I fall asleep!?" miserably, she asked herself. "I could have done something, given dad a better chance..."

Sydney buried her face into her hands, sitting near the edge of her driveway, struggling to compose herself as the rain continued to fall. She remained there for several moments before something blew into her lap in the wind. Pausing, she lowered her hands and was surprised to find a torn piece of fabric from a denim shirt or jacket. She picked up the fragment and saw that it was a sewn on badge of some sort. "What is this?" shaken, she asked.

The badge was an insignia of some kind. It was eight swords, forming a star, with a ring in the center that held a star within it. Sydney had never seen such an insignia but then it dawned upon her that, whatever it was, dad must have torn it off the clothes of his kidnapper. Who ever had taken him belonged to whoever the insignia represented. Determined to find answers, Sydney limped back into the house where she first...

112.content:
Ignoring the pain in my bare feet, I limped into dad's room and began to search for anything that might tell me who had taken him and why. Normally, I never dared to venture in as he was always so protective of his belongings. He had explained that it was an impulse with childhood origins, living in a bad neighborhood. "Where to start..." Sighing, I asked myself. "His desk, perhaps..."

I carefully moved through his papers but found nothing of use other than we were far more well off than he had led me to believe. Or was that a clue? I looked deeper into the financial records and found that our wealth had exploded only about a year before when dad took on a new job with some unknown agency. It was definitely a clue. I moved on to his filing cabinet only to find that it was locked. Not to be detoured, I pulled a hair pin and began to pick the lock. Something I had learned from a rather detailed mystery novel series I enjoyed reading. Within seconds, the filing cabinet was unlocked.

"What do you know..." smiling, I muttered. "It actually worked."

Combing through the files, I found that dad had worked on a number of high level cases for this agency only I could not find the name of it. All the files said was Employer One in reference to who dad was working for. I moved to the last file in the cabinet and found an incomplete case which had a picture of the very insignia I had found on the road while chasing the suspect car.

"The Agenda Guild." Reading the file, I said. "So that is who took dad. He must have been close to blowing their operation wide open."

I looked back through the other files, hoping to find some contact number but found nothing useful. I then turned back to the Agenda Guild file and found three possible people in three locations dad was considering investigating. Each person had a file describing them and possible connections to the Agenda Guild. After acquiring all I believed I would need for my own personal mission, I decided to fly to...

113.content:
It took hours for any useful information to come out of researching obsessively the insignia on the badge, She had taught about just giving it up, not bothering with this goose chase and doing what any other sane person would do in this situation. Her father was well known around the village, respected and powerful. There would be police checking every backwoods and overturning every stone to bring him back.

Sydney took a sip from her hot tea and continued to read messages on her computer. As an anonymous account, she had posted the image of the eight swords on all the forums she could find. It had been a long night already of dealing with Internet trolls and false leads.This could be so much easier.

She shook her head remembering the few instructions that her father had left behind in case he "mysterious disappeared." The number one rule was that the authorities could not be involved. At all. Sydney had lived in the mansion and enjoyed the finer things in life without thinking much of how her father made the family fortune. Now it seemed any of his business partners could've been slighted or a ex-employee has plotted revenge. With no leads and her tea no longer having effect, Sydney drifted away at the desk with the thought of the swords swirling around. Her father was yelling for help, he was somewhere dark, as if it was an underground maze. Beep!

She woke up from her dream to a find a flashing notification on the screen. After reading the message and doing some cross reference, it turns out that the poster has given her the identity of this insignia. It belonged to...

1133.content:
Disappointed and mostly embarrassed, Sydney logged off and closed her laptop. When she clicked on the link, she first felt her heart drop, waiting in anticipation for the page to load. When it finally did, it was like the past hours had been a complete waste! Worse, she was not any closer to figuring out where her father was or if he was even alive.

"What the hell is this?" She had mumbled to herself. The website was clear. It was from some upcoming MMO-style game for VR headsets. Not like she cared about anything like that, but sure enough, on the main page there was that symbol again. The eight swords and star looked even brighter and yet more ominous in high resolution. But that was it, there wasn't even much more information on the game except that it would be released in the near future.

Sydney thought about something that did show up on the webpage. It was small, a list of the sponsors but with no leads, it didn't seem like a bad idea to try checking.

She opened the laptop again. Scrolling past the graphic of the insignia, she found a small listing for the organizations that had made funding possible. Right at the top of the list was the Sawyer Foundation and a picture of a grinning man in glasses. "There you are, Dad... Since when are you into video games?"

With all of her family resources and unlimited time on her side, Sydney decides her next course of action.

11331.content:
Sydney clicked around the website again with no major leads. She was able to find an address for the company but when she looked it up online, the only available image was a nondescript row of warehouses in the hi-tech San Bernardo area. It was nice to have a physical location as a last resort but there was no guarantee that anybody would actually be there. For all she knew, it was a server farm where their data just passed through.

She couldn't stop thinking about the importance of her father's organization, the Sawyer Foundation, being on the company's website. Finally she realized that if she was going to find out where he was or what he was up to, she was going to have to break some of the rules. She didn't have many rules living at home but going into her father's office was definitely a big one.

He had either been in a rush or had been distracted enough to be careless because the door to his office was unlocked. The inside of the study was a messy desk filled with paperwork and surrounded by the towering shelves of her dad's private library. He wasn't much of a reader and instead had an eye for collecting rare manuscripts and priceless 1st editions.

Sydney goes through the desk, briefly looking at the paperwork which is mostly budget statements for the foundation and a list of upcoming media-focused activities. It seems like nothing that can help until she finally found what she was looking for. An outgoing statement of bank transfers and payments. At first it doesn't seem like any sort of gaming company is listed but it is clear that they have to be under a fake name.

One name caught her eye as well as the over a million dollars that had been donated or issued in the form of mysterious, semi-frequent payments. SAMSARA LLC appeared all over the banking statements. Could this be the mysterious gaming company that had left its promotional material in her father's mansion?

113311.content:
Sydney couldn't believe how much easier things had gotten with finding a paper trail. It was one of the things that her father had always stressed to her.

"Follow the money! Follow the trail." She heard his voice in her head, it hadn't been that long ago when they would watch conspiracy theory documentaries when he had downtime. She on the other hand, didn't have much going on. Her father had offered her a position countless times, but she always refused. She told him she would make it out on her own, thank you very much. But that never happened either. Instead it seemed like years since she'd last had that conversation and spent so much time already wandering the lonely mansion.

The resources really were a blessing. Especially at a time like this.
Sydney sat at her desk and clicked frantically to book the next available plane tickets to... Burma? That couldn't be right, could it? She had called in a favor and was able to find the physical address for this Samsara company. Once there was money involved, there was no hiding, especially from the well-connected financial advisors her father had on retainer. As for any suspicions? None at all from them. Her father had given her plenty of security clearance and authorization to handle his account in the event that he wasn't unavailable.

With a poor excuse of Mr. Foxtrotter being at the hospital with a stomach bug, Sydney had gained access to more money than she ever thought possible. And it wasn't even a considerable portion of her father's fortune.

"I guess I am going overseas..." Still unsure if this was her father testing her or a genuine emergency, she purchased the planet tickets for a flight that was hours away. Then it was a hurry to pack, there wouldn't be much time left and she wanted to leave the country in case the bank had notified someone she'd have to worry about.

1133111.content:
The terminals of Yangon International Airport were empty when Sydney arrived. She was jet lagged, exhausted, and despite the couple of champagne glasses that she had for breakfast, still very nervous about the rash decision to hop on a plane and try to find out her father. Was it really this crazy? What if her father was just testing her? Making sure she went through with the plan instead of wasting away on a couch.

It just didn't seem his style. Could he really have expected her to find herself thousands of miles across the sea in a foreign airport, not speaking a word of the language, and still on his trail? Sydney had her laptop out and looked around the airport for the next step in her search. Surprisingly, Samsara was not located in the developing tech sector of the city, but inconveniently located in a highly mountainous region.

This is when she began to suspect that this really wasn't a joke. As much as her father loved mind games, he wouldn't put her in danger, even if it was for the sake of a lesson on independence.

With all the tourism that passed through the region, Sydney found it quite easy to communicate with the workers at the airport. A helpful young man directed her to a set of stands by the exit into the city where she could request additional services such as a ride share or hotel accommodations. Still, if her father was in danger, she had to be vague with whoever she contacted. Just enough information to get to where she needed to.

113312.content:
"Arthur, this is Syd. I'm sorry it is so late but I am looking up something urgent for Dad."
Sydney was a terrible liar. A stomach bug? Really? She had known Arthur for most of her life since he was not only a close family friend, but her father's highly trusted accountant.
Art handled anything and everything involving the family fortune, handling shadow accounts, securing tax benefits, and taking a generous fee simply for making sure they all didn't go broke. He was sometimes terrible at his job, as she had heard her father complain, but for the elder Foxotter, he was as close to a real friend as anybody could be.

"No, he's fine. Just a bug."
She tried to be casual about it. Arthur requested the spoken code to access further information. This wasn't the first time she had dealt with some issue for her father when he was too busy or couldn't be bothered to deal with it. It wasn't suspicious, but for some reason, Art was extra insistent on hearing the codeword, one of many that her father had in place for security and confirming transaction.

"Snowflake. I said, snowflake. Art, seriously! I need these records tonight."
Sydney thought she sounded too desperate. Would he be able to detect that something was wrong? Did he already know her father was missing and he was just playing along with the game? She sighed in relief when the accountant confirmed he was sending an encrypted file.

"While you're at it, Dad also wants all future transactions canceled. Bad investment, yes. I am surprised he never discussed it with you. Virtual reality, yup. It just didn't pick up like he thought it would."

Sydney said goodbye and ended the phone call with a click. She opened up her laptop again and waited. The logo of the E-Secure website began to look blurry. Exhaustion creeped up on her and her eyes were strained from the glow of the screen. It had been hours of trying to find answers and now she had what seemed like a bread crumb. It wasn't much longer when she finally nodded off on the keyboard.

But instead of having a deep sleep until the morning, she woke up with her heart pounding and her body spiking with adrenaline. Bang! There was a crash coming from downstairs. It sounded like a window was being smashed.

12.content:
What was that all about? What just happened? Where is my father?

Questions rushed around her mind, floating there as she stood in the destruction that was her father's room. Her first and only thought was that he had been kidnapped. Kidnapped. The word sounded alien to her. Why would someone want to kidnap him? He was a self made man and he did have quite a lot of money, but something deep within nagged her. She got the feeling it was about something more than money, but what?

She hobbled from the room and to the middle of the hall where the bathroom was, ignoring the pain in her feet. As she took a perch on the side of the bath and located the first aid kit, she began pulling out shards of glass from her feet. She hardly felt the pain. Her mind was a whirlwind of chaos. What just happened? She had always suspected there was something about her father he didn't tell her, but everyone had their secrets, right? But what if his secret got him kidnapped? I have to find out.

With her feet firmly bandaged she set the first aid box down and stood up, wincing at the sharp pain in her feet. She vaguely wondered if she'd gotten all the glass before her mind moved back to her father. What now?

122.content:
She moved back in to the hall, limping slightly, where something on the table there caught her eye. It was her Father's mobile phone. Only recently she had convinced him to upgrade his old model to a more modern Smartphone. She smiled to herself at the memory, then reached out for the device and switched it on.

Her first thought was to check his call history. Just before she did so, she hesitated. Was this a breach of her Dad's privacy? How would she feel if he went nosying through HER private calls? But this was an emergency - she hadn't disappeared in to the night, possibly snatched by some kind of lunatic stranger and he had, so under the circumstances she felt justified. The last few days call history was unsurprising - the University he sometimes worked for, a local pizza place, his bank, Eliza, the lady who came to clean the place every now and then. The most recent person he had spoken to was his friend Arthur - Sydney knew him well and had done since she was a young child - he was one of her fathers oldest friends. Without further consideration she pressed the call icon. It rang a few times and a middle aged man's voice came on.

"Hello? Jack?"

"Hi, Arthur? It's Sydney here, it's Jack's daughter, something's happened. My Dad -" Something instinctively told her to stop. Maybe she had read too many thrillers but suddenly she didn't feel safe talking on the telephone. What if it was bugged? What if this was something way more serious and complex than she could imagine?

"Sydney?" Arthur's tone was worried. She realised she hadn't spoken for a while.

"Arthur, is it okay if I come over to speak to you? I'll explain when I get there."

"Of course! Are you okay? Is everything okay?"

"Yes, I'm okay, I'm sure everything will be fine. I'll make my way over, thanks Art". She cancelled the call and stuffed the phone in her pocket, then made her way back over to her room where she grabbed her bag and coat and pulled a pair of boots over her bandaged feet.

Just as she began to descend the stairs, she heard a crash come from the direction of the kitchen.....

1223.content:
Instantly she crouched low as she crept over to the balcony on the second floor. As she peered through the bars down onto the expansive lobby, she saw only darkness punctuated by shadows. There was no movement. She didn't expect to say any, not there anyway. She carried her bag down the steps with her, each pace she took downwards muffled by the carpet on the stairs. She was glad her father had opted for that one. She left the bag at the bottom of the stairs in case she needed it for a quick getaway and slowly made her way to the back of the house where the kitchen was.

Her boots thudded quietly on the tiled floor and she walked deliberately, placing her feet down one by one and being as quiet as possible. She made it to the kitchen door where another thunderous crash from inside had her jumping. Her heart thumped wildly in her chest as she reached forward and rested her hand on the door.

Slowly, she pushed it open. It moved without sound and inside she could make out the shape of the island in the centre of the kitchen, the utensil rack hanging above it hanging by one chain and half of the items scattered across the kitchen top and floor. She smiled at herself and let out a grunting laugh. The nights events had caused her to be jumpy. She supposed it was natural but boy did she feel stupid. She reached into the room with her hand to flick on the light when...

12232.content:
Suddenly, a hand reached out from the darkness and grabbed Sydney's hand before turning her violently as a second hand clasped firmly over her mouth. Sydney screamed through the hand but nothing but a muffled whimper escaped as she felt herself being dragged into the shadows. She started to struggle but a familiar whispered voice caused her to hesitate. "Be still if you want to live!"

Sydney froze, recognizing the voice of her uncle Jack who she thought was out on a business trip in the former Soviet Union. Jack kept a firm hold onto her hand, holding the other securely over her mouth as she heard an unnatural sound that sent a chill down her spine. It sounded like a child's scream but distorted, as if through an old metal pipe. Then she saw the dark figure of what looked like a child come into view. Only, as it turned its head, Sydney saw that it was not a child, at least not anymore. Half of the creature's face was metallic, like that of a broken doll only worse. Its one eye was blue but the other was red, searching the darkness for movement. It rose its hand to look at a paper in its hand and Sydney saw that it was human except for the hand; it was robotic!

For the longest time, Sydney remained still and silent as the odd creature looked about then moved on, letting out another haunting scream and was gone. It was several long moments before Jack released Sydney and allowed her to turn to face him. "What- What was that thing?" shaken, Sydney asked. "It looked like a little boy but..."

Jack was a powerful man, standing at six foot five with muscles that would make an Olympian weight lifter jealous. He brushed his longish black hair aside, revealing his deep blue eyes. "That 'thing', as you put it, is a little boy." sadly, he replied. "Your father and I have been working hard to stop the monsters who had 'created' them."

Hearing this horrified Sydney. "What!?!" almost screaming, she asked.

"They are called 'The Collective'." serious, Jack explained. "They are a group of mad scientists who have pulled their resources to bring humanity into what they see as the next evolution of mankind."

"By turning kids into machines..." shaken, I asked. "That's insane!"

"Your father and I have been fighting this group for decades." after looking about, Jack said. "Your mom has been fighting them too.... from the inside."

"Mom is with those maniacs!?" horrified, Sydney asked.

Jack nodded. "Your father did not want you to know this but now they are onto us and that places him, me, you all in danger."

"Someone took dad." gulping, Sydney said.

"I know." almost whispering, Jack said. "They took him but..."

"But what?"

Jack came down to my level. "Sydney, they were after you."

Sydney's eyes went wide before she...

123.content:
Sydney crawled on the floor and back to her bedroom. She reached for her cellphone on the side table next to her bed. She dialed 911 and she told the operator everything.

The police were there within a few minutes. She knew that the influential Foxotter name would catch the authorities' attention right away.

The Foxotter's butler, Lloyd, had been downstairs near the foyer when the police arrived. It was as though he had been expecting the cops when he answered the door. Sydney studied his demeanor to see if he was unnerved, but Lloyd was expressionless. All of their servants were trained to act that way.

Detective Dalton asked Sydney questions as the police searched her property. Had she seen or heard anything suspicious? Did anyone threaten her? Had her father been acting differently lately?

Sydney knew that to have any chance of finding her father, she had to figure out why he had been taken. Ignoring the pain that shot up from her foot, she began to scour his room. She started by the window where she already was but besides the rain that was lashing through the open pane, there was nothing to be seen. She hobbled over to the upturned bed. It was a double mattress with a metal frame which suggested to her that whoever had done this was really strong, either that or there was more than one of them. The thought chilled her.

The dressed showed nothing. He kept only small trinkets in there and items for cleaning and getting ready. The familiar smell of Old Spice floated up to her and her stomach sank. Will I ever see him again? She shook herself. Sydney was a woman who prided herself on being strong and not wallowing and now was not the time to start.

The last things in the room were his wardrobe and his bedside table. As she searched she found...

133.content:
Sydney held the amulet on the gold chain in her hand. Was it valuable? Why had it been stashed in a sock? She knew her father kept his cufflinks and rings and other trinkets in a small leather trinket box. Why not the amulet as well?

She walked over to the lamp so that she could see it better. It was round and made of gold and seemed very old. The design was simple - a chameleon. A golden chameleon. What could it mean? She could not escape the feeling that she had discovered something important. Yes, it was only "intuition" at work, but Sydney trusted her intuition. It had helped her on more than one occasion, even saved her life once.

Should she call the authorities now? If she waited much longer, they would ask why she hadn't called them immediately. How could she answer: "Because I know my father would not want the police involved and I was hoping to figure out who took him myself."

No, that wouldn't do. It was not that her father was a criminal. He wasn't, not really. But he had political enemies who could easily spin public opinion in that direction.

info.brief_description: Help Sydney as she travels the globe looking for her father...
info.description:
Sydney Foxotter is a young woman who is smart, beautiful and wants to get whatever she can out of life. Things are going really well and she's enjoying her life when her father is snatched from their mansion one dreary, stormy night in October. Determined to find him, Sydney goes looking for him and travels across the world, vowing nothing will stop her unravelling the mystery of her father's disappearance.

Take Syndey wherever she needs to go to find her father and unravel the mystery. Feel free to have her partner up with someone or seek expert advice. Remember to keep it rated ASR or below!
